And while Trump also wants to repeal and replace ObamaCare, some Republicans have turned squeamish about sweeping changes to the health law.At the Barclays Industrial Select conference in Miami, Bornstein said he is "reasonably confident" that the changes will get passed in 2017, but said investors could be "very disappointed" if they aren't."If we don't get corporate tax reform across the goal line in 2017,  if we don't provide some visibility to where health care is going in 2017, and if we don't deliver on all the regulatory changes the administration has talked about in 2017, I think we could end up in a very difficult place," he said.On Tuesday, GE CEO Jeffrey Immelt — along with CEOs from Boeing (BA), United Technologies (UTX) and other industrial exporters, as well as drugmakers Celgene (CELG), Eli Lilly (LLY), Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE) — wrote a letter urging congressional support for the House's tax reform blueprint, which includes a border adjustment tax.A total of 16 companies signed the letter, but more than 100 companies (including Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT) and Nike (NKE)) and dozens of trade groups have signed on to Americans for Affordable Products, a group created to oppose the import tax.GE shares fell 0.6% to 30.33 on the stock market today. Boeing shares were off 0.1%. United Tech rose 0.1%.Last month, as talk of repealing ObamaCare began ramping up, GE's Immelt also indicated that some customers could become more cautious."If I took it by segment, the Affordable Care Act is getting the most attention in the media and by our customers," he said on a conference call after reporting mixed Q4 results. "I think you could see some caution around the Affordable Care Act as you go forward. We haven't really seen that much. But that could happen."Trump said at a rally in Florida over the weekend that a replacement plan for ObamaCare won't be coming for "a couple of weeks." He warned earlier that the process could last until next year.Meanwhile, markets are still waiting for the White House to detail its own tax proposals, as those from congressional Republicans take more flak.Last week, Trump told retail CEOs that a "massive" tax plan will come "in the not-too-distant future." That followed his remarks to airline CEOs in the prior week, when he vowed to announce something "phenomenal in terms of tax" in the coming weeks.RELATED: If Border Tax Dies, Trump Corporate Tax Cut May CollapseTrump Silent On Ex-Im Bank, Hints At 'Big' Boeing Super Hornet Order

Security stocks in general rose Tuesday as analysts weighed in with upbeat reviews for last week's RSA Conference, one of the security software sector's biggest annual events.Proofpoint (PFPT) retook a buy point Tuesday, while Palo Alto Networks (PANW) was eyeing one.IBD's 27-company Computer Software-Security industry group came within pennies of a more than two-month high in early trading in the stock market today, and it was up 0.6% at the close Tuesday. The group ranks just No. 125 out of 197 groups, but that's up from No. 175 eight weeks ago and No. 151 four weeks ago.IBD'S TAKE: Security software isn't currently a hot industry, but there always are some hot groups, and you can go in-depth on the top industries by tracking IBD's Industry Snapshot feature.Analysts in general expect security software companies to rebound in 2017 after a soft 2016. Security spending cooled off in 2016 after a series of high-profile breaches at Target (TGT) and JPMorgan (JPM), among others, sparked a big jump in security spending in 2014 and '15."Security remains a top priority for IT, and budgets are growing," Rosenblatt Securities analyst Marshall Senk wrote in a research report Tuesday. "Our research points to the majority of organizations with budget increases."Said William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho in his report Tuesday: "We attended the RSA Conference last week and came away incrementally positive on the cybersecurity space, based on our meetings with public and private companies."Proofpoint stock ended trading Tuesday up 2.1% to close at 83.56. That's back within the buy zone from a breakout last month at 82.81, out of a cup-with-handle base. Shares are trading near two-month highs.Ho praised new features launched by the company."Proofpoint released new features for its social media product to broaden its reach to the digital media market," he wrote. "The new solution includes capabilities to monitor URLs and websites for potential spoofing and trademark infringement from malicious users."Senk cited Proofpoint product partnerships with the likes of Palo Alto, Splunk (SPLK) and CyberArk Software (CYBR), saying that "the partnering strategy, driven

around deep partner integration, is beginning to pay dividends."Palo Alto Networks stock, meanwhile, rose 0.7% Tuesday, to 155.80. But it was up just a fraction Tuesday afternoon, near 155. The stock has been forming a cup base with a buy point of 165.79.Speaking of Palo Alto, Senk wrote that "we look for another transitional quarter on the product side, with partners reporting stronger pipeline builds for both the back half of this year (July) and into F18." The company's fiscal year ends on or near July 31.Ho, too, praised Palo Alto's product announcements at RSA, a five-day event in San Francisco that ended Friday.Ho said the event attracted more than 43,000 attendees, easily topping last year's record attendance of around 40,000. The show also attracted more than 550 exhibitors, he said, which he said included nearly 120 first-time exhibitors.RELATED:Cloud, IoT, Arby's Hack Featured At RSA'Nimble' Proofpoint Takes Market Share

CEOs of Dow stocks General Electric (GE), Boeing (BA) and 14 other big U.S. exporters are warning that unless Republicans embrace a controversial tax on imports, a once-in-a-generation chance at tax reform will fail and American workers would be the losers."Our tax code penalizes American workers who make products or provide services sold abroad, while favoring their international competitors," the CEOs wrote in a letter to leaders of both parties in Congress.Among other companies whose CEOs co-signed the letter were Caterpillar (CAT), Dow Chemical (DOW), Raytheon (RTN), United Technologies (UTX), Oracle (ORCL) and some of the biggest drug and biotech companies: Celgene (CELG), Eli Lilly (LLY), Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE).Caterpillar, Merck, Pfizer and United Technologies also are members of the Dow Jones industrial average, in addition to General Electric and Boeing.The letter puts some of the largest U.S. companies squarely behind House Speaker Paul Ryan and other House GOP leaders, who argue that leveling the international playing field by cutting the U.S. corporate tax rate to 20% (or lower) will be impossible without their plan for a 20% tax on imports, which would raise $1 trillion over a decade.Yet the biggest surprise about the letter may be just how few companies signed it, while more than 100 companies, including Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT), Nike (NKE) and the American subsidiary of Toyota (TM), and dozens of trade groups have signed onto the Americans for Affordable Products, created to oppose the House border tax proposal. (Wal-Mart and Nike are also Dow industrials stocks.)Retail stocks were under pressure from early December, as prospects for a border tax were on the rise, but they've made a modest recovery lately as prospects faded. On Tuesday, perhaps helped more by Wal-Mart's positive earnings report as well-received Macy's (M) earnings than weighed down by a revved-up lobbying campaign for the tax, retail shares were on rise. Wal-Mart rose 3% to close at 71.45 on the stock market today, while Target added 0.6%.IBD'S TAKE: Supporters of the border tax plan say that the dollar would rise by 20% vs. other currencies, meaning that it wouldn't harm either corporate profits or consumers. But it does pose a risk to U.S. investors holding shares of companies like Alibaba or international ETFs.Under the House proposal for a border-adjusted tax, U.S. companies would pay a 20% tax rate on the full value of imported goods, while export revenue would be tax-free. The border tax would raise more than $1 trillion over a decade to offset the cost of lowering the 35% statutory tax rate to 20%, the conservative Tax Foundation has said.Without the border tax, the ability of Congress to reduce the U.S. corporate tax rate will be limited to "incremental tweaks (that) will not level the playing field for American workers or dramatically reinvigorate economic growth," the CEO letter said.It's not clear precisely why so few companies came out in favor of the border tax. Although the proposal seems to be running into a buzz saw among Republicans in the Senate, it's possible that the letter wasn't widely circulated. However, Caroline Freund, senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, has predicted that "many more big lobbies will be against the BAT (border-adjusted tax) than in favor." That's because the tax favors labor-intensive industries that export more than they import, with aerospace being a rare example.There's one nagging question about why companies such as GE and Boeing that are so dependent upon exports would back the border tax. Most trade experts who have looked at the tax have big doubts that it would comply with World Trade Organization rules, so it could lead the U.S. into a trade war. Given that uncertainty and the possible consequences, it's hard to understand why companies so dependent upon trade would support the border tax, yet that may partly explain why the list of supporters is so small.RELATED:If Border Tax Dies, Trump Corporate Tax Cut May Collapse GOP Border-Tax Plan Would Sock U.S. Tourism — Including Trump Hotels

Shares of Whole Foods (WFM) on Wednesday eased closer to Amazon's (AMZN) $42-per-share offer, as rival bids have so far failed to materialize.After acquisition deals are announced, shares often trade just below the per-share value offered when markets assume a merger will likely go ahead as planned.But in the days following Amazon's announcement earlier this month that it would buy Whole Foods in a $13.7 billion deal, shares of the upscale grocer reached an intraday high of nearly 44, a sign Wall Street was preparing for bigger bids.Speculation over a competing bid centered on Wal-Mart (WMT), which has been swallowing up e-commerce sites in an attempt to stay abreast of consumers' ever-digitizing shopping habits. Kroger (KR) and Target (TGT) were also said to be on a list of potential bidders.But Wal-Mart is reportedly not considering a Whole Foods offer.Shares of Whole Foods fell 0.7% to 42.25 on the stock market today, their fifth straight decline. Amazon climbed 1.4%, Wal-Mart edged up 0.7%, Kroger surged 2.55%. Target fell 1 cent.RELATED:What Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailAmazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, Eateries

Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) reportedly is not considering an offer for Whole Foods Market (WFM), dashing hopes that the retail giant could spark a bidding war after Amazon's (AMZN) $13.7 billion deal for the high-end grocer.As of Friday, Whole Foods also has not received any bids countering the Amazon offer, sources told Reuters.Whole Foods stock vaulted nearly 20% last week after Amazon reached a deal to buy the grocer for $42 a share. The stock extended gains this week amid hopes of a bidding war for the natural foods company.In addition to Wal-Mart, Kroger (KR) and Target (IBD) were said to be on the list of potential bidders.Shares of Whole Foods closed 0.6% lower at 42.94 on the stock market today, after rising as much as 43.84 intraday, and lost another 0.1% in late trade. Amazon added 0.2% to 1,003.74, and Wal-Mart ended 0.9% lower at 74.84. Kroger edged up 0.2%, and Target rose 0.25%.RELATED:Whole Foods Stock Signals Another Bidder Is Coming, But Who?Are These Amazon's Next Five Targets?What Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailAmazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, Eateries

Amazon (AMZN) sparked mass panic in the grocery and retail space when the e-commerce giant said it was buying Whole Foods Market (WFM), but everyone should calm down and stop clutching their pearls about megaretailer Wal-Mart (WMT), argues Moody's.X "While the deal will certainly help Amazon's competitive position in the grocery business, the proposed deal still falls well short of being a real threat to Walmart, which remains the world's biggest retailer and grocer," wrote Moody's analyst Charles O'Shea on Wednesday, adding that Wal-Mart is expanding its footprint at a time when other brick-and-mortars are shrinking.He sees Wal-Mart's food business accelerating at a quick clip, highlighting the company's in-store pickup feature as its "latest weapon." Wal-Mart CFO Brett Biggs said in May that the company's online grocery service had expanded to 670 locations.For the select areas where Walmart Grocery is available, many shoppers can get same-day delivery, similar to Amazon's grocery-delivery service, Amazon Fresh. And Wal-Mart's Jet.com acquisition last year for over $3 billion has helped the retailer try to keep pace with Amazon's sprawling e-commerce tentacles.IBD'S TAKE: As Whole Foods' share price creeps higher than the 42-per-share that Amazon offered, some speculate that Amazon may not even be the final bidder: Whole Foods Stock Signals Another Bidder Is Coming, But Who?Notably, even with the pickup of 460 Whole Foods stores, Amazon still doesn't have the on-the-ground reach of Wal-Mart's more-than-5,300 physical locations (including Sam's Club). Biggs has also said that 90% of Americans have access to the big-box store within a 10-mile radius."Our view for the short to medium term is that for Walmart this moves the competitive needle a mere smidge," said O'Shea in a separate note out Wednesday. "Realistically speaking, a challenged $16 billion food retailer is merely changing owners. And Walmart, already the world's largest retailer, also is the world's biggest grocer."Amazon, an IBD Leaderboard stock, rose 1% to 1,002.23 in the stock market today. Whole Foods Market climbed 1.1% to 43.26, as investors still see a rival offer.Wal-Mart shares climbed 0.9% to 76.24, third third straight modest gain after tumbling 4.7% Friday and breaching their 50-day moving average for the first time since February after the Amazon-Whole Foods deal was announced.Shares of Kroger (KR), Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM), Target (TGT) and others are also still trying to recover from the news. Kroger retreated fractionally on Wednesday, while Sprouts fell 0.5% and Target 0.75%.Citi Research downgraded Target to neutral from buy on Wednesday, citing challenges from Wal-Mart and now Amazon.RELATED:Amazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, EateriesAre These Amazon's Next Five Targets?What Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailWal-Mart Beefs Up Online Ops With $310 Million Bonobos Deal

Costco Wholesale (COST) reported 7% sales growth in June to $12.17 billion and 6.5% in same-store sales growth for the month excluding gas prices and currency. But big questions remain about how the membership discounter will thrive as Amazon (AMZN) buys Whole Foods Market (WFM) and roils ever more retail sector.XFor the five-week period in June, Costco's U.S. same-store sales grew 6.3%, above consensus of 3.7%, according to Stifel. Core Canada comps rose 6.8% and other international comps grew 7.1%. There are 734 Costco warehouses worldwide; 511 of them are in the U.S. and Puerto Rico.The U.S. comp included 4.5% U.S. customer traffic, which BMO Capital Markets analyst Kelly Bania said is "particularly impressive considering the continued challenging trends experienced across other parts of retail and Amazon fears."She maintained an outperform rating and 185 price target.Costco shares fell 0.6% to 157.09 in the stock market today after trading at 161.35 soon after the market open. The stock is well below its 200-day and 50-day moving averages after plunging on June 16, the day Amazon announced its acquisition of Whole Foods Market, a move that caused panic throughout the retail and grocery sphere.Costco's June results appear to have bolstered Wall Street's confidence in the members-only retailer."We also think the results indicate Costco can coexist with large hard line competitors like Wal-Mart and have limited cannibalization from Amazon," wrote Stifel's Mark Astrachan late Wednesday.Other grocery names haven't shaken off the hit. Kroger (KR) remains below its 50-day and 200-day, sinking 18.9% on its June 15 earnings report and another 9.2% the following day on the Amazon-Whole Foods announcement.Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) managed to retake its 200-day but remains below its 50-day. Target (TGT) has been trading below its 50-day since the news. Wal-Mart (WMT), the No. 1 grocery seller, tumbled below its 50-day moving average and has yet to bounce back.The question of when Amazon can begin rolling out grocery delivery appears to be a matter of when, not if, with Piper Jaffray estimating that the e-commerce titan can target upper-income households within 18 months.Amazon fell 0.6% as big-cap techs renew selling after Wednesday's rebound fell just short of its 50-day line. Meanwhile, Whole Foods Market rose 2 cents to 42.01 after closing Wednesday just below Amazon's 42 offer price as investors give up on Kroger or Wal-Mart making a higher bid.RELATED:Is Amazon Closer To Fulfilling Dream Of Fast Grocery Delivery?What Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailAmazon Is Buying Whole Foods For $13.7 Billion; Grocery Stocks Dive

The Nasdaq composite edged down as Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and other big techs remained under pressure. The S&P 500 index closed below its 50-day moving average on Thursday but moved higher Friday. Tesla (TSLA) crashed amid a variety of news that raised concerns, while auto sales slumped overall. Job growth was solid amid a variety of upbeat June economic data.XThe Nasdaq rose 0.2% for the week after hitting its lowest levels since May 19. The S&P 500 closed below its 50-day on Thursda but rallied for a 0.1% weekly gain. The Dow industrials, buoyed by financial components, hit an all-time high Monday and was closed the week up 0.3%, even as General Electric (GE) and Verizon (VZ) dived to 21-month lows. Tesla plunged amid weak Q2 deliveries, Model 3 news and a less-than-stellar safety rating. The latest Federal Reserve and European Central Bank meeting minutes indicated that policymakers are moving toward tightening policy, weighing on stocks and lifting global bond yields.The U.S. added 222,000 jobs in June, more than 170,000 expected, while April and May payrolls were revised higher. The jobless rate unexpectedly ticked up to 4.4% as more people looked for work. Average hourly wages advanced 0.2%, a little less than expected. Meanwhile, the ISM manufacturing index for June rose to the best in years while the ISM nonmanufacturing gauge showed still-strong expansion.For the second straight week, U.S. investors paid more attention to the European Central Bank than to the Federal Reserve. Both central banks released minutes from their June meetings.Economists interpreted the Fed minutes as indicating a bit more uncertainty about whether inflation will rebound and, thus, about the Fed's rate trajectory. Still, absent a surprise, the Fed seems likely to announce in September that it will gradually scale back its $4.5 trillion balance sheet, inflated with Treasury and mortgage bonds purchased in response to the financial crisis.The ECB's policy signals have been jarring because they represent a pretty dramatic, if gradual, potential change from the central bank's long-running asset-purchase program.ECB President Mario Draghi indicated last week that the eurozone monetary authority could begin scaling back its asset buys, which economists now expect to happen by early 2018. The ECB minutes from the June 7-8 meeting revealed that policymakers discussed dropping language from future meeting statements saying that they're prepared to reverse course and increases asset purchases if conditions demand.Tesla CEO Elon Musk announced that the closely watched Model 3 has passed all regulatory inspections, signaling that production will start Friday and announcing a "handover party" on July 28 for the first 30 customers. He predicted a rapid ramp up in production. Late Monday, the electric car maker announced that its second-quarter deliveries climbed 53%, but were at the low end of expectations. Goldman Sachs, reiterating a sell rating, cut its price target to 180 from 190, while several other analysts noted some concerns with Tesla's data and outlook. Meanwhile, Tesla's Model S failed to get the IIHS' top safety rating. Tesla stock suffered its worst weekly loss in 17 months.U.S. auto sales fell 2.9% in June to a 16.4 million rate and are now down 2.1% so far this year. General Motors (GM), Ford Motor (F) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) saw sales drop 5%, 5% and 7% respectively year over year, while Toyota Motor (TM), Nissan (NSANY) and Honda Motor (HMC) grew sales modestly. Overall, the industry posted its sixth straight month of falling or flat sales, despite higher use of incentives. Consumers continued to spurn the car segment for SUVs, crossovers and trucks. Sales of new vehicles have slowed this year as freshly off-lease vehicles have flooded the market. Even the red-hot SUV segment is starting to show softness. June sales came in at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 16.4 million, the lowest rate of the year.An eight-day win streak came to sharp end on Wednesday, while even a sharp drop in U.S. crude and gasoline inventories couldn't give prices much of a boost. U.S. crude fell 3.9% to $44.23 a barrel for the week. The Energy Information Administration said U.S. crude stockpiles fell by 6.3 million barrels last week vs. analyst expectations for a 2.3 million barrel draw. Gasoline supplies dropped by 3.7 million barrels, also more than expected. But domestic crude production bounced back to 9.34 million barrels per day after falling to 9.25 million BPD in the prior week. Russia reportedly said it wouldn't agree to any further production cuts when a committee of top OPEC and non-producers meets in St. Petersburg on July 24.Microsoft (MSFT) plans to lay off up to 3,000 workers as part of a reorganization to focus on cloud-computing services. The layoffs are mostly in sales and amount to less than 10% of the Microsoft's sales force. About 75% of the layoffs will be outside the U.S. Microsoft is shifting its business from on-premises software for PCs and servers to cloud-based software subscriptions for products like Office 365 and Azure. Microsoft said the reorganization is more about better using its resources than about cost-cutting.Samsung and Alibaba (BABA) are the latest companies entering the increasingly crowded market for voice-activated smart speakers, which is now led by Amazon.com's Echo devices. Chinese e-commerce leader Alibaba announced its Tmall Genie X1, which has voice controls for online shopping, playing music, getting news and weather, and other functions. The Mandarin-language Genie will be much cheaper than the Amazon Echo and especially the upcoming Apple HomePod. Alibaba rival JD.com (JD) already has a smart speaker on the market. Samsung is working on a device code-named Vega. Other Chinese firms entering the space include search engine Baidu (BIDU) as well as gaming and messaging giant Tencent (TCEHY).Samsung announced huge preliminary second-quarter profit Friday, predicting operating earnings of $12.1 billion, which suggests the Korean electronics giant will top Apple's quarterly profit. That's was likely largely due to booming memory chips, but also possibly good sales for the Samsung Galaxy 8 smartphone.Yum China (YUMC) topped earnings but fell short on sales. The spin-off and China licensee of Yum Brands (YUM), which owns KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell, highlighted its mobile and delivery sales, which have become more important to attracting tech-savvy, convenience-seeking diners. Mobile payments surpassed 40% of sales during the quarter; delivery made up 13%. Yum China also said it had acquired a controlling interest in the holding company of the delivery service Daojia. Yum China shares tumbled 12.9% on Thursday but pared its week loss to 5.35%.Delta Air Lines (DAL) said Q2 unit revenue would land in the upper range of its outlook and tweaked higher its operating-margin forecast. The carrier said "an improving revenue environment" helped counterbalance the scores of cancellations it suffered in April because of powerful thunderstorms in the Atlanta area.Casino stocks pulled back on softer-than-expected Macau gaming revenue for June. Gross gaming revenue rose 25.9% to 20 billion patacas ($2.49 billion), short of the midpoint of forecasts for 23%-33%, according to Reuters, marking the 11th consecutive month of casino revenue growth in the wake of the Chinese government's corruption crackdown. MGM Resorts International (MGM) lost 1.4% for the week after tumbling nearly 5% on June 30. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) dropped 3.3%, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell 1.2% and Melco Resorts (MLCO) sank 3.4%.Vantiv (VNTV), a credit-card and payment-processing company, will buy British payment-processing company Worldpay Group in a stock-and-cash deal worth about $10 billion. Worldpay said it selected the Vantiv offer over one from by JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which said it did not intend to make a counteroffer. Vantiv generates the bulk of its revenue from fees associated with payment-processing services for merchants. Clients include Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT) and Macy's (M).Bankrate (RATE) shares jumped after the online provider of financial services for consumers agreed to be acquired for $1.4 billion by Red Ventures, a privately held internet advertising and media company.General Electric tumbled 3.8% on Thursday to a 21-month low after JPMorgan saw an uncertain and limited outlook for the industrial giant, while the European Union accused GE of not disclosing information during a merger review.Shares of O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) plunged 19% to 178.77 Wednesday after the retailer announced same-store sales grew 1.7% in the second quarter, well short of expectations. Peers Advance Auto Parts (AAP) and AutoZone (AZO) tumbled in sympathy to multiyear lows.Volvo, owned by a Chinese billionaire, vowed a "historic" shift to all-electric or hybrid vehicles by 2019. It will end production of cars powered solely by the traditional combustion engine. China is becoming the biggest market for electric cars.

Dominance in e-commerce, new growth opportunities and having one of the best management teams on the planet are among the reasons cited by RBC Capital Markets for reaffirming its outperform rating on Amazon.com (AMZN) just ahead of quarterly earnings, but the investment bank warned that profit margins could slip.Amazon reports fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Thursday. Analysts estimate revenue of $44.7 billion, which would be up 25% from Q4 2015 and maintain a steady string of double-digit growth going back more than four years. Analysts expect earnings per share minus items to rise 35% to $1.35.RBC analyst Mark Mahaney, in addition to his outperform rating, set a price target on Amazon of 950.Amazon stock lost 0.8% to close at 823.48 on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon is gaining ground in large retail markets beyond its core markets of electronics and media, putting the e-commerce giant in position for a strong performance in 2017.Mahaney, in a research note, said foreign currency exchange rates could mean "greater than normal risk to Wall Street estimates" on operating income for Q4 and Q1, despite signs of a strong holiday sales season for Amazon.Amazon is also investing heavily in India and other international markets, as well as building multiple fulfillment centers and investing heavily in original video content and other projects, all of which will continue to weigh on profitability, he wrote.But Amazon remains a core long-term hold, Mahaney wrote, saying its two key markets — e-commerce and cloud computing — are only about 10% penetrated, with the company posting year-over-year growth rates that are "extremely consistent and inherently very impressive."Needham analyst Kerry Rice, in a research note, said he expects Amazon to meet earnings estimates, but not beat. Overall e-commerce sales growth during the holiday sales season only met expectations, "given the slower-than-expected start as consumers focused their attention on the presidential election instead of holiday shopping," he wrote.Rice also agreed that foreign exchange headwinds "could limit growth upside." Rice has a hold rating on Amazon stock.In addition, Rice wrote, "We believe a more competitive landscape could slow the rate of Amazon's market share expansion."Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT), he wrote, are gaining ground in e-commerce sales. Wal-Mart has added to its e-commerce strength with its $3.3 billion acquisition of Jet.com.Rice also says that Amazon's Q1 operating guidance could disappoint, as the company remains in a heavy investment cycle.But in a research note late Sunday, Pacific Crest Securities said Amazon was the clear sales winner this holiday season, which should dampen concerns that its continued heavy investments could cause an earnings miss. Pac Crest also said growth and profit margins for the company's cloud business, Amazon Web Services, "should remain robust despite pricing fears."Among other internet stocks, Facebook (FB) is set to report earnings after the market close on Wednesday.Wall Street expects Facebook to report revenue growth of 46% to $8.5 billion — the second quarter in a row of revenue deceleration, attributable in part to a deliberate move by Facebook to cool the growth in advertising to avoid saturation, analysts have said. EPS is expected to rise 66% to $1.31.RELATED:Amazon Sets Q4 Earnings Date As Prime Customers Flex MusclesAmazon Reportedly Ends Talks To Acquire Stake In Middle East E-Com LeaderAmazon Plants A 'We're Hiring' Sign To Reach 100,000 New Jobs

Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Tesla's (TSLA) quarterly report will be the most eagerly anticipated of the week, while Mobileye's (MBLY) comes as it and ex-partner Tesla charge ahead on autonomy. Continental Resources (CLR) and other top shale producers will report, along with fiber-optic stock Acacia Communications[ticker…

Wal-Mart (WMT) announced Tuesday that it will offer free two-day shipping for minimum orders of $35, giving up on its version of Amazon (AMZN) Prime.Wal-Mart had pushed ShippingPass, with a $49 annual membership fee, but it never took off. ShippingPass members will get a full refund.The $35 minimum order is down from $50, while the free-delivery window was cut from five days. Products shipped to stores will have no price minimum."In today's world of e-commerce, two-day free shipping is table stakes. It no longer makes sense to charge for it," said Marc Lore, CEO of Wal-Mart's e-commerce efforts.Lore came from Jet.com, an Amazon rival that Wal-Mart bought last year as part of efforts by the discount giant to revitalize e-commerce sales.Wal-Mart, Target (TGT) and many other retailers have spent heavily to beef up their online operations. But their e-commerce growth comes from a low base, appears to be lagging the gains of much-larger Amazon, while brick-and-mortar stores continue to see declines.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon tested its buy point, but other FANG+ stocks had key technical moves Monday.Amazon reports fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday.Wal-Mart shares rose 1.2% in Monday stock market trading, but after hitting an eight-month low on Friday. Amazon stock dipped 0.6% to 830.38 after briefly undercutting its 821.75 buy point intraday.RELATED:Amazon's Stellar Holiday Season Will Offset Continued Heavy SpendingTrump Slump Stocks Wal-Mart, Macy's, Other Retailers Rally

The Dow Jones industrial average and other major indexes hit record highs as President Trump made more noises about tax reform, while Fed chief Janet Yellen took a slightly hawkish stance. Apple (AAPL) rose to an all-time best while fellow Dow stock Verizon Communications (VZ) returned to unlimited wireless plans. Kraft Heinz (KHC) is pursuing a mammoth deal for Unilever (UN). NetEase (NTES), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and NetApp (NTAP) rallied on earnings, while General Motors (GM) may sell its European unit Opel.The Dow industrials and Nasdaq composite rose 1.8% for the week, with the S&P 500 added 1.5%, all hitting new highs during the week. Apple was a key contributor to all the major indexes. Fed Chair Janet Yellen's somewhat hawkish tone didn't worry investors, but gave bond yields and bank stocks a boost."Waiting too long to remove accommodation would be unwise," Fed chief Janet Yellen told Congress, a shift from her 2016 tone emphasizing downside risks to the economy. Yellen, along with other Fed officials speaking during the week, raised the odds of a near-term hike slightly. Markets don't expect a March move but see a 50-50 move by May and a strong likelihood by June.  Yellen warned against repealing financial regulations passed after the credit crisis.Meanwhile, retail sales and inflation data were stronger than expected, while small-business optimism hit a fresh 12-year high and the Philly Fed manufacturing index shot up to its strongest reading since 1984.RELATED:Worries over intensified wireless competition pressured phone company stocks after Verizon Communications (VZ) reintroduced unlimited data plans nearly six years after removing them. Verizon sought an edge over T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) by offering high-definition video as part of unlimited data. T-Mobile quickly changed its offer to include HD video. Sprint cut its unlimited price to $50 a month or $90 for two users, including HD video. AT&T (T) opened unlimited wireless beyond DirecTV and U-verse customers. Analysts say industry consolidation could ease competition. Merger talks are expected to heat up when a government spectrum auctions ends, perhaps by late March.RELATED:T-Mobile (TMUS) on Feb. 14 reported Q4 profit and revenue that edged views. For 2017, it forecast branded postpaid subscriber additions of 2.9 million, below estimates. Analysts called the guidance conservative, though in any event T-Mobile will likely lead industry subscriber growth for the fourth year in a row in 2017. For the first time, T-Mobile provided free cash flow guidance. It forecast three-year FCF annual growth of 45% to 48%, or about $4.5 billion by 2019.Softbank is willing to give up control of its majority-owned Sprint to achieve a merger with T-Mobile, Reuters reported Friday. Sprint rose 3.3% on Friday and T-Mobile 5.5%, with AT&T and Verizon rising modestly that day.RELATED:Apple, the top Dow industrials stock in 2017, hit a record high of 136.27 on news reports related to its cash-return plans and the upcoming iPhone 8. Apple reportedly increased its order of OLED displays from Samsung for its 10th-anniversary smartphone, due out in September. CFO Luca Maestri said Apple would look to boost dividends and buybacks if the U.S. cuts corporate tax rates, as expected under President Trump.RELATED:Kraft Heinz (KHC) signaled it will continue to pursue the European consumer and food products giant even though Unilever (UN) said the offer undervalued the company and sees no reason for further talks. A combination would be one of the largest of all time and create a global food giant. Kraft Heinz, which has been slashing costs to boost profit, shot up 10.6% Friday to a record high. Unilever leapt 15.3% to 48.79, also setting a record best. Snacks giant Mondelez (MDLZ) fell. Consumer products firms such as Kimberly-Clark (KMB) rallied.RELATED:President Trump on Wednesday met with CEOs from Target (TGT), Gap (GPS), AutoZone (AZO) and other retailers, saying he would cut regulations and encouraging them to expand in the U.S. Trump also said a "massive" tax plan was coming "in the not-too-distant future." Target, afterward, warned that a GOP plan for a border adjustment tax as part of corporate tax reform would force them to "raise prices for American families on everyday essentials." That subject came up during the meeting, although it was unclear how much of a focus it was.RELATED:Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) gobbled up shares of Apple (AAPL) in Q4, quadrupling its holdings, according to a regulatory filing. He also continued to fill up on Delta Air Lines (DAL), American Airlines (AAL) and United Airlines (UAL). David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital also boosted its stake in Apple. Appaloosa cut its stake in the iPhone maker but hiked its stake in Southwest (LUV). George Soros took stakes in Facebook (FB), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Delta, but dropped United. Activist investor Trian Fund Management built up a $3.5 billion position in Procter & Gamble (PG).RELATED:The Chinese mobile gaming giant late Wednesday reported Q4 earnings per American depositary receipt of $4.40 minus items on revenue of $1.74 billion, both well above the analyst consensus. Online game revenue rose 63% in local currency to $1.29 billion. NetEase said it added 40 mobile titles in 2016, and in December it announced 14 new PC and mobile games. NetEase licenses many games from Activision Blizzard (ATVI), including "World of Warcraft" and "Overwatch." NetEase stock leapt 14% on Thursday to a record high after edging past a buy point earlier in the week.RELATED: In its fiscal Q2 ended Jan. 28, Cisco earned 57 cents per share minus items, flat from a year earlier but topping views by a penny. Revenue fell 2% to $11.58 billion, the fifth straight decline, but that beat expectations of $11.55 billion. Cisco's deferred revenue from software and subscriptions jumped 51% to $4 billion in fiscal Q2, a sign that its shift to software and services from its core business of selling network switches and routers is gaining momentum. Cisco shares rose 7%, hitting their best levels since November 2007.RELATED:Chip gear maker Applied Materials (AMAT) earned 67 cents a share ex items in its fiscal Q1, up 158% year over year, on sales of $3.28 billion, up 45%. Analysts expected 66 cents and $3.27 billion. It was Applied Materials' fourth straight quarter of accelerating sales and EPS growth. For fiscal Q2, Applied Materials sees strong earnings and sales growth that are above Wall Street models. Applied Materials shares rose 1%, near 16-year highs.RELATED:Data storage systems provider NetApp reported earnings and guidance that topped views. Revenue of $1.4 billion edged past the consensus of $1.39 billion and was its first top-line growth in 13 quarters. NetApp rose 4.2% on Thursday, moving back above a 39.10 buy point from a cup base.RELATED:U.S. crude futures fell 0.9% to $53.40 a barrel for the week. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries now sees non-OPEC supplies growing by 240,000 barrels per day, double it prior estimate, as drilling and investment pick up in the U.S. OPEC also said in its oil market report that its production fell by 890,200 bpd in January. Saudi Arabia had the biggest decline in output. U.S. crude stockpiles jumped by 9.5 million barrels, according to the Energy Information Administration, well above analyst estimates. But stocks at the Cushing, Okla., hub were down. The number of U.S. oil rigs in operation rose yet again. Diamondback Energy (FANG) reported Q4 results above Wall Street views and raised its full-year production outlook and capital-spending target. Devon Energy (DVN) also reported Q4 results above expectations.RELATED:Peugeot's parent, PSA Group, said it was in talks with General Motors (GM) about potentially acquiring the U.S. automaker's Opel division, which also includes the British Vauxhall brand. The deal would give PSA Group a 16% market share in Europe, second only to Volkswagen (VLKAY). GM has had trouble turning a profit at the unit and had a tentative deal in 2009 to sell it to Canada's Magna.RELATED:One big health insurance merger, between Aetna (AET) and Humana (HUM), is dead, while the other, between Anthem (ANTM) and Cigna (CI), broke out into a wrestling match. Federal judges blocked both deals earlier this year. Cigna sued Anthem for $13 billion in damages on top of a $1.85 billion breakup fee. But a judge blocked Cigna from ending the merger after Anthem countersued, arguing that Cigna has tried to sabotage the deal.Humana, which gets a $1 billion payment from Aetna for its trouble, moved on by announcing a stock buyback and saying it will exit the ObamaCare exchanges. Aetna's CEO said the ObamaCare exchanges are in a death spiral. And Molina Health (MOH) signaled it would likely exit the ObamaCare exchanges next year.UnitedHealth (UNH) tumbled 3.7% Friday on news that the Justice Department has joined a whistleblower suit accusing the health insurer of overcharging Medicare Advantage by hundreds of millions of dollars, possibly billions of dollars. Other health insurers, including Aetna and Humana also retreated Friday.RELATED:DOJ Accuses UnitedHealth Of Overcharging Medicare AdvantageSnap (SNAP), in an updated SEC filing, says it's looking to 200 million shares at a price range of 14 to 16 a share, raising roughly $3 billion. That would give it a valuation of $19.5 billion to $22.2 billion, below earlier reports that the Snapchat parent would seek $25 billion. Snapchat enjoys rapid revenue growth, but Facebook (FB) is successfully imitating Snapchat features, especially on its Instagram app.RELATED:U.S. Steel (X) flirted with a buy point during the week while Steel Dynamics (STLD) and Nucor (NUE) and aluminum maker Alcoa (AA) jumped on reports that China is considering sweeping production cuts to combat smog. Reuters reported that China could slash steel capacity by at least half and aluminum capacity by 30% in certain months.Cement and aggregates firms, like steel companies, are expected to benefit from President Trump's infrastructure push, as well as a multibillion-dollar wall on the border, but that won't help 2017 results much. Martin Marietta Materials (MLM) on Tuesday missed fourth-quarter earnings and sales estimates and gave a subdued 2017 outlook.RELATED:Las-Vegas-centric MGM Resorts International (MGM) turned profitable in Q4, reversing a year-earlier loss, but missed estimates, while revenue was in line. Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), which operates out of gaming hub Macau and elsewhere in Asia, topped views on sales but missed on EPS. Macau has been trying to recover after the Chinese government launched an anti-money-laundering crackdown.  MGM fell 9.3% on Thursday to a three-month low. Melco fell 4.5% after briefly retaking a buy point in the morning.RELATED:ON Semiconductor (ON) rose 10.1% through Thursday, hitting its best levels since August 2000, after the chipmaker on Sunday reported adjusted EPS rose 53% and sales climbed 50%, both beating. Q1 guidance also was strong.Shopify (SHOP) hit a record high after the e-commerce platform provider reported Q4 earnings that topped views as revenue grew 86% to $130.4 million. Q1 revenue guidance was strong.Mobileye (MBLY) and Volkswagen (VLKAY) will partner in the development and deployment of self-driving cars. The two will implement "a new navigation standard for autonomous driving starting in 2018." Mobileye already has an autonomous-car deal with BMW. It also is sharing data with Here, a mapping service owned by German automakers including BMW and VW's Audi.

A yawning trench of dirt, wood and exposed cables currently sits at the mouth of the Westfield Century City in west Los Angeles. The Apple (AAPL) store is still open and the Tesla (TSLA) showroom has been moved to a different spot, but much of the shopping center remains under construction.When it reopens this year, it will have expanded into a glamorous 1.2-million-square-foot beast of a mall — 422,000 square feet larger — complete with Italian food emporium Eataly, hip burger joint Shake Shack (SHAK) and "new high-fashion streetside boutiques."XIn fact, the Century City mall won't just be a mall, it will be "an immersive sensory experience unprecedented in the modern retail space," according to a 2015 Westfield press release. This location hardly needs a tuneup. With $1,457 in sales per square foot, it is the ninth-most productive mall in the country, according to a CNBC story from May, citing real estate research firm Green Street Advisors. So why spend $800 million on a makeover?Looks matter more than ever, particularly as social-media bragging rights become an essential part of the millennial shopping experience. So these days, every retailer has to put on a good show, ramping up the drama to boost foot traffic and cheat death as Amazon (AMZN) spells doom for more and more American malls."(Young people are) very into cataloging everything they do via social media, and so these more luxury experiences have more social currency," said Talmage Advisors CEO Liz Dunn.That could mean Snapchatting from inside a Tiffany (TIF) — regardless of whether you buy something — or taking a topside photo of your artisanal lunch. (Never has flat lay photography been so popular.)"Whatever it is, there's a lot more social currency to that than saying 'I'm at a TGI Friday's,' " she said.The mall's transformation into an "immersive sensory experience" contrasts with the post-World War II bloom of malls, which attracted Americans to cookie-cutter hubs with their one-stop-shopping convenience. That has since given way to the splendid isolationism of two-day shipping via Amazon Prime, hollowing out traditional malls and forcing the survivors to become purveyors of experiences that can be shared online.Fellow L.A.-based shopping center The Grove, owned by Caruso, underscores the trend and is a social-media maven's dream.It houses many of the same stores as a regional mall does — like Banana Republic, J. Crew and Anthropologie — but also features a fountain, trolley and live music, helping put it at No. 2 on CNBC/Green Street Advisors' list with a $2,200 in sales per square foot. The photogenic plaza was even once the backdrop for Hollywood-gossip show "Extra," which has no doubt upped its social cred among tourists who want a glimpse of glam."This is where all the B-list celebs, YouTube stars, and Instagram influencers shop (I saw an Instagram male model there myself when I went)," gushed one Yelp reviewer visiting from Toronto.The lure of exclusivity, that close cousin of luxury, is another way retailers have amped up the theatrics.It's a tactic long employed by an athletic-footwear industry that routinely releases shoes in small batches, driving up demand from sneakerheads and high-schoolers alike. There's even a sneaker stock exchange, StockX, devoted to the resale of Jordans, Kobes and anything Kanye has ever designed for Adidas.Other retailers have since caught on. Coach (COH) and Disney (DIS) last year introduced a limited-edition House of Mouse-themed handbag line. Spice Girl-turned-fashion designer Victoria Beckham is behind Target's (TGT) upcoming capsule collection. And H&M seems to have an endless series of designer linkups in the pipeline.The New York Times even declared 2016 "the year of the drop," referring to the slew of limited-edition releases and pop-up shops, like Kylie Jenner's blink-and-it's-gone store, designed to create shopper frenzy.The Hollywood Reporter called the December opening of Jenner's pop-up, located within the Westfield Topanga Mall in Los Angeles' San Fernando Valley, "mayhem."Mayhem is the antithesis of convenience, when it comes to shopping. But that is the point. No one wants to stand in line outside for hours waiting for laundry detergent. A Kylie Lip Kit, however, is not long for this world.To get a teen or 20-something to the mall — and most "drop" shoppers are under 30, noted the Times — the mall must act a little more like a nightclub, velvet ropes and all.Even supermarkets are in on the action: Some Whole Foods Market (WFM), Kroger (KR) and Gelson's locations feature wine bars, a premium add-on meant to keep grocery shoppers in stores longer.Such theater may seem gimmicky, but it works, and is also being seen in actual theaters. The local cineplex, a requisite component of any shopping mall, is also undergoing a revamp.On the defensive from Netflix (NFLX) and massive TVs, theaters have been making screens bigger, audio better, and seats more spacious. And as an alternative to grabbing popcorn from the concession stand and trying to find a decent seat, more theaters now serve cocktails and dinner to your reserved Barcalounger while that summer blockbuster plays in Imax 3D.AMC (AMC), for example, embarked three years ago on a $600 million reseating project to rip out traditional chairs and replace them with recliners.AMC, which has called its collective upgrades a "winning playbook," outlined at a recent presentation that attendance has grown 53% and revenue leapt 70% in its 1,500 or so reseated theaters. It has thousands more theaters in line to be updated.Top exhibitor chain Regal Cinemas (RGC) also recently attributed recent outperformance to plush seating, calling out recliner sites as the "biggest driver.""Theaters have to do something to differentiate themselves from the in-home experience," said RBC analyst Leo Kulp. "That's really what's driven these investments over the past several years."Theaters, full-service restaurants and other bells and whistles have woven themselves into a successful mall's narrative, but it may be a while before the experiential stuff surpasses retail stores that sell shirts and shoes."The future will certainly bring less retail, but it will take a few years to tip the scale" so that retailers become a mall's minority residents, said NPD Group retail analyst Marshal Cohen.There is also some hope for once-reliable mall anchors like Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), even as Macy's reportedly considers selling itself after a brutal holiday season.The Grove has a Nordstrom, and the revamped Westfield Century City is actually adding a department store to the mix, for a total of three major names. It will now house a two-story Macy's, three-story Bloomingdale's and a three-story Nordstrom that is being relocated from the next mall over.But the massive upgrades being made to shopping arenas could even further widen the gap between top-market malls and their less-moneyed brethren.Of the more-than-1,000 malls in America, the 300 or so top-market "A-malls" account for 75% of mall value (a metric comprised of sales productivity, size and other factors), according to Green Street Advisors.So what's a midtier mall to do? For developers, the answer may be: Change or die.Strong anchors are "imperative" for a shopping center's long-term viability, according to Green Street's 2017 mall outlook report, since income-generating tenants want malls with "vibrant," traffic-driving anchors.As department stores waver, Green Street's research points to restaurants, movie theaters and "traditional power-center tenants" — like Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and pet stores — as rising power players.But Talmage Advisors' Dunn is not optimistic."The problem is, it's a little bit of a self-fulfilling prophesy," she said. "The landlords aren't willing to invest in the lower-tier centers, and the thing that would potentially take a lower-tier center to help it jump a bracket is investment. But it's hard to justify the investment if the center's performance isn't in that top-tier range."

Wal-Mart (WMT), Macy's (M), Gap (GPS) and other retailers rose Monday as investors sold "Trump rally" stocks and perhaps lowered the odds of tax reform that could sock merchants.Wal-Mart rose 1.2% on the stock market today. But that's after Wal-Mart hit eight-month low on Friday. Target (TGT) edged up 0.7%, Macy's 1.4%, Dollar Tree (DLTR) 1.6% and Gap 1.3%.Retailers tumbled at the end of last week after the White House hinted that it might back the House GOP tax reform plan that includes a 20% border-adjustment tax. House Republicans have said they see the border-adjusted tax, which applies to imports but not exports, as a critical part of tax reform because it would raise more than $1 trillion to help pay for slashing the corporate tax rate to 20%. Retailers, which are huge importers, fear the plan will slam their profits.President Trump's immigration order could end up hurting the odds of tax reform and other key parts of Trump's fiscal agenda. That's because with a thin GOP majority in the Senate, he can't afford to alienate potential allies.IBD'S TAKE: Apple and Boeing are among six Dow stocks in buy range to start the week. But three of these blue-chip stocks dipped below entry areas amid Monday's market retreat.Separate from Trump and his tax and trade policies, brick-and-mortar retailers face an near-existential crisis as shoppers continue to shift online. While Wal-Mart, Target and others are beefing up e-commerce efforts, Amazon (AMZN) appeared to dominate online holiday sales growth. Investors will get an idea of how strong Amazon was when it reports Q4 earnings late Thursday.Amazon shares fell 0.6% to 830.38 after briefly undercutting its 821.75 buy point intraday.RELATED:Why Trump Immigration Order May Weigh On StocksTrump Immigration Ban Sinks Delta, American, UnitedTrump Tax Fears: Wal-Mart, Target, Macy's Hit New Lows

Republicans are beginning to coalesce around a high-risk strategy to deliver a major corporate tax cut that has remarkably high odds of blowing up on them.The White House signaled on Thursday that President Trump is seriously considering the House GOP plan to cut the corporate tax rate to 20% and cover much of the cost by imposing a 20% tax on imports, while making exports tax-free.The proposal faces a bruising political battle as major importers like Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT) warn that they — and their customers — could be slammed by what opponents have labeled a "consumer tax" on imported goods. Shares of Wal-Mart, Target and many retailers retreated on the stock market today, hitting multi-month or multi-year lows.While some economists are confident that the exchange rate between the dollar and other currencies would seamlessly adjust to neutralize the impact of the border tax, other economists and industry analysts warn of a potentially jarring impact. Prices could rise even on vehicles built in the U.S. by General Motors (GM) and Ford (F) because few models are composed of at least 75% domestically sourced parts. Goldman Sachs has warned that U.S. "oil prices would appreciate immediately and sharply vs. global oil prices."Expect Democrats to line up behind corporations warning that the poor and working class will bear the brunt of the GOP border tax — even though the tax-reform approach emerged from the George Soros-funded Center for American Progress and it might not sound so bad to labor unions.Yet concerns about price spikes aren't the primary risk. A gradual transition to the new tax regime likely could minimize near-term market disruptions, and the law could even include triggers to slow down a ramping up of the border tax if inflation starts to percolate.The real risk for Trump and Republicans is that the border-adjusted tax may violate World Trade Organization rules. A wide array of experts believe a negative WTO ruling is likely and even supporters say it's a real possibility.Republicans have said they're willing to take their chances at the WTO, and it's not hard to understand why they're willing to roll the dice. Without the $1 trillion-plus raised by the 20% border tax, Republican leaders see no palatable way of making a major cut in the corporate tax rate revenue neutral in the intermediate term, which is necessary to avoid a filibuster and pass via reconciliation.The border tax is the GOP's magic bullet that will pay to fix the U.S. corporate tax code and may even pay to build a wall on the border with Mexico. But what if there is no magic bullet? If the WTO declares the border tax to be illegal, the GOP would face three unpleasant choices: repeal the border tax and blow a bigger hole in the widening deficit; replace it with one of the options that Republicans are currently ruling out as untenable; or keep it in place and invite other countries to retaliate in ways that would hurt the U.S. economy.IBD'S TAKE: Big exporters like Boeing could have a negative tax rate under the GOP tax reform plan.This scenario isn't written in stone. The WTO could find that the border-adjusted tax regime complies with international trade rules. But with so much doubt about the outcome, the GOP is effectively jumping off a cliff and hoping that its parachute opens, much like it would be doing if it repeals ObamaCare before passing a replacement.The tax reform panel appointed by President George W. Bush considered a border-adjusted tax but eventually ruled it out, citing "uncertainty over whether border adjustments would be allowable under current trade rules, and the possibility of challenge from our trading partners."To understand why there's a good case the border-adjusted tax would violate WTO rules, consider first how White House press secretary Sean Spicer described the border tax on Thursday in discussing how a tax on imports from Mexico could pay for Trump's wall.Spicer said that applying a border adjustment tax, as "the plan that's taking shape now" would do, "is, by the way, a practice that 160 other countries do."Yet there's a distinct difference between the value added tax that 160 other countries impose and the border-adjusted tax that the White House is considering. The key is that other countries apply the VAT regardless of whether a product is imported or produced at home.By contrast, writes Caroline Freund of the Peterson Institute for International Economics, "The cash-flow tax proposed in the House is discriminatory. The tax on domestically produced goods would be less than the tax on imports."In fact, the very reason that the GOP finds this border-adjusted-tax acceptable is that — unlike a VAT — it doesn't apply to the wages involved in making or selling a product. Basically, the tax on imports would apply to the full value of an import, while the tax on domestic goods would only apply to the positive cash flow that is generated from the sale.If the WTO rejected the border-adjusted tax, the logical fix would be to remove the wage deduction, effectively turning the tax into a nondiscriminatory VAT, argues Freund. Yet, she adds, since shifting to a VAT would raise consumer prices and have a disproportionate impact on low-income and poor households, Congress would have to take steps to solidify the safety net.The problem with this scenario is that Republicans are terrified of a VAT, which they see as offering a slippery slope to keep raising taxes incrementally.It's not clear that the other main alternative to pay for a corporate tax cut — a big hike in taxes on capital gains and dividends — would be any more appetizing.How it all would play out is unpredictable, but it seems possible that the fallout could dent or upend the GOP majority. Meanwhile, the uncertainty could undo the positive effects corporate tax reform is supposed to have in making it more attractive to do business in the U.S.RELATED:Trump Backs 20% Import Tax To Pay For Border Wall — Or Not Trump Trade: What He Can Do Legally On Nafta, China, Mexico, Taxes

XWhole Foods Market (WFM) shares continued to climb Monday, signaling increased belief that someone else could top the $13.7 billion Amazon.com (AMZN) deal for the high-end grocer.Barclays analyst Karen Short said she "would not be surprised if there is a bidding war" for Whole Foods, upgrading the high-end grocer to overweight from equal weight and raising her price target by 26% to 48, well above Amazon's announced acquisition price of 42 a share.A fresh bid could be as high as 57 a share, Short says, giving a big potential upside. Meanwhile, the regulatory risk for Amazon's deal is low, so the potential downside from buying Whole Foods shares is low in her view. And beyond fending off the e-commerce giant, Short added that a strategic retail bidder could create up to $600 million in synergies.Is this a plausible scenario? Barclays isn't the only one that seems to think so. Oppenheimer upped its price target to 45 on Friday, not long after the deal was announced, on the grounds that the deal undervalued Whole Foods' prospects and "powerful brand." Analysts there see a mid-40s-range buyout as more appropriate.Shares of Whole Foods Market rose 1.3% to 43.22 in the stock market today — even after closing up 29.1% on Friday to 42.68.So who, exactly, could pop out of the woodwork to beat Amazon's $13.7 billion offer? In Short's view, the list of suspects is long: "all retailers that sell food and compete with (Amazon) because we think most have too much to lose not to bid." Kroger (KR), Target (TGT) and Wal-Mart (WMT) are on that list.The nation's grocery chains and big-box stores have already lost a lot since Friday, as shares of Kroger, Target, Wal-Mart and Costco (COST) suffered mightily from the merger announcement.(The only grocery retailer that isn't getting further kicked Monday on news of the deal is Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) — and that's likely because Oppenheimer pegged it as the next possible takeover target. Sprouts rose 3.5% on Monday.)Kroger rose 1.6%, but after crashing nearly 28% last week. Wal-Mart edged up 0.3% while Target fell 1.7%.Costco continues to suffer Monday, falling 2.7% to a 2017 low and undercutting its 200-day moving average. Deutsche Bank downgraded Costco to hold, citing intensifying competition from efforts by Amazon and Wal-Mart to ramp up their in-store and online business.The Whole Foods acquisition "represents a game changer with (Costco's) competitive moat of grocery under greater threat while its digital platform lags peers, putting membership renewal at higher risk for decline," wrote Deutsche's Paul Trussell. He cut his price target on Costco to 172 from 187.Still, the membership warehouse's traffic and margins are solid, he said. And Cowen's Oliver Chen, who has an outperform rating on Costco, believes the retailer's vertical integration and low prices will continue to be brick-and-mortar traffic drivers.For his part, Chen isn't so sure that Costco would be interested in — or Target would be capable of — proposing a buyout for Whole Foods, and Wal-Mart might only have interest insomuch as a buyout would be a defensive measure. But he is wondering about Amazon's next shopping spree."We believe there are likely capabilities, routes to market, and specialized brand propositions at retailers which could be synergistically combined with largely pure-play online retailers such as (Amazon)," wrote Chen.Who? Why, Nordstrom (JWN), Urban Outfitters (URBN), Ascena Retail Group (ASNA) or even RH (RH) (formerly known as Restoration Hardware).Those might be some pretty unexpected names for a potential Amazon takeover — but then again, so was Whole Foods.RELATED:Are These Amazon's Next Five Targets?What Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailAmazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, Eateries

Wal-Mart (WMT) beefed up its online portfolio Friday, announcing that it will acquire men's clothing retail startup Bonobos for $310 million in cash as it battles Amazon (AMZN) in the e-commerce market.The news coincided with Amazon's own acquisition of Whole Foods (WFM) for $13.7 billion Friday.Discount retailer Wal-Mart has been on a shopping spree of its own in the past year as it steps up its digital strategy. Last month, Wal-Mart-owned Jet.com announced it was buying ModCloth, a vintage-inspired women's apparel e-tailer. Earlier this year, Jet.com announced the acquisition of Shoebuy from IAC (IAC) for about $70 million, and Wal-Mart inked a deal to buy online outdoor retailer Moosejaw for $51 million. Wal-Mart purchased Jet.com in August 2016, and on Friday said the channel "continues to provide a strong avenue for reaching an urban, millennial customer."After the deal closes, Andy Dunn, founder and CEO of Bonobos, will oversee the company's online consumer brands and report to Marc Lore, the president and CEO of Wal-Mart U.S. e-commerce."We're seeing momentum in the business as we expand our value proposition with customers and it's incredible to see how fast we're moving," Lore said Friday.In its most recent quarter, Wal-Mart saw 63% growth in U.S. e-commerce sales, the majority coming from organic growth in Walmart.com. Since the start of 2017, Walmart.com has unveiled two-day free shipping with no membership fee, extra discounts for picking up orders in stores and easy ordering online and in stores.The Bonobos deal is subject to regulatory approval and is expected to close near the end of the second quarter or the start of the third quarter of this fiscal year, Wal-Mart said.Shares of Wal-Mart plunged 4.6% to 75.26 on the stock market today, gapping down below their 50-day line. Among rival discounters with big grocery businesses, Costco (COST) dumped 7.2% and Target (TGT) 5.2%.Amazon rose 2.4% to 987.71. Whole Foods shot up 29.1% to 42.68, above the 42-a-share deal price.RELATED:Amazon Is Buying Whole Foods For $13.7 Billion, Roiling SectorWal-Mart's 4th E-Commerce Deal In 4 Months May Cost $300 Million

X Unhinge jaw, devour Whole Foods Market (WFM). Amazon's (AMZN) latest acquisition is its largest ever at $13.7 billion, and one that promises to shake up the retail space — though exactly how is unclear.A combined Amazon and Whole Foods Market would create the fifth largest U.S. grocery retailer behind Wal-Mart (WMT), Kroger (KR), Costco (COST) and Albertsons/Safeway, said Cowen analyst John Blackledge in a Friday note.As Investor's Business Daily has previously reported, Amazon's foray into the grocery aisle isn't new. Through Amazon Fresh and Prime Pantry, Amazon already has some level of grocery-delivery built into its fulfillment strategy, though the complexity of handling produce and perishables at its fulfillment centers means that the rollout has been relatively slow.It was not until the latter half of 2016 that Amazon "meaningfully ramped up its expansion efforts" to be in approximately 20 major U.S. markets, wrote Blackledge in an earlier report from March.Engulfing Whole Foods now brings 460 additional brick-and-mortar locations in the U.S., Canada and the U.K., and around 87,000 more employees to Amazon's arsenal. Whole Foods raked in $16 billion in sales in fiscal 2016.That expanded presence in the real world could mean all manner of retail ripples. Amazon could use the acquisition to increase its product offering through Prime Now or expand its beta-tested curbside pickup offering, among other things, noted Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson. The e-commerce titan could also incorporate its private-label items, "compressing costs and removing differentiation currently enjoyed by retailers like (Wal-Mart)."Whole Foods will expand Amazon Fresh's potential footprint to most of the U.S., especially in upscale areas, Olson added. "We believe Amazon can therefore launch nationwide grocery delivery coverage within 12-18 months."For Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM), "it will likely complicate its delivery partnership with AMZN through Amazon Prime Now," wrote UBS analyst Michael Lasser. Amazon and Sprouts announced a Denver grocery delivery partnership on Thursday.Additionally, "we consider it to be a negative read for (Target), as it could further complicate its efforts to gain traction creating a stronger, better-for-you food offering in its stores," he said.The buyout could also increase the existing allure of Amazon's Prime membership.In the cybersphere, Amazon Prime was already the "most used" platform to buy groceries online in 2016, according to a Cowen survey from March. Prime's 47% share outguns Wal-Mart 39% piece of the pie, and Cowen's Blackledge added that the U.S. grocery retail market is "greatly underpenetrated online," projecting earlier this year that online grocery sales could reach $177 billion in 2022, up from an estimated $71 billion this year.And there appears to be plenty of room to grow within Amazon's own ecosystem: Consulting firm Magid said only 13% of Prime subscribers buy groceries on Amazon.Analyst reaction has been swift. BMO Capital Markets upped its price target on Whole Foods to 42, Amazon's offer price. Oppenheimer raised its target on Whole Foods to 45 from 40, and said it can't rule out the possibility of another bid for the upscale grocer as a defense measure against Amazon.Some investors apparently agree with Oppenheimer. Whole Foods shares shot up 29.1% to 42.68 on the stock market today. Amazon rose 2.4% to 987.71.Calling the buyout a "somewhat surprising step" from Amazon, RBC analyst Mark Mahaney also noted surprise that Amazon is wading further into brick-and-mortar retail.The question of what Whole Foods can bring to Amazon appears to be answerable in a dozen different ways. A murkier question appears to be what Amazon can do for Whole Foods."We could see AMZN perhaps improving WFM's procurement processes, but it's very unclear to us how Amazon would improve the rest of WFM's operations," said Mahaney, noting that Amazon "has typically not bought fixer-uppers.""So we see substantial execution risk here, offset only by the reality that in the AMZN scheme of things, this is actually a relatively modest acquisition," he wrote.UBS' Lasser sees potential for "deeper price investments" at Whole Foods, which he says is "necessary" to re-accelerate same-store sales growth at the grocer.Looking to Amazon's peer in China might offer some clues about what comes next in the plan."If you look at Alibaba (BABA) and what they've been able to do in China with the grocery stores that they've invested in, that might be a model, but you don't know because Amazon is always going to be on the forefront," ACSI Funds CEO Phil Bak told Investor's Business Daily. Amazon and Whole Foods Market are both holdings in the company's fund.Alibaba recently inked a deal with Chinese supermarket heavyweight Shanghai Bailian Group, which has 4,700 locations in the country, and the China e-commerce giant has an approximate one-third stake in Sanjiang Shopping Club.Amazon "is not following anyone else's model," said Bak. "They're going to pave the way, and they're going to create a new model for how grocery shopping can be."One thing is clear: This massive acquisition means that the list of Amazon-proof stores is getting smaller."As other brick and mortar retailers have come to realize the hard way that competing with Amazon is a formidable challenge, supermarkets will now have to contend with not only competition with each other and nontraditional grocers like Wal-Mart and Target, but with a retailer like Amazon which has the financial capacity to price aggressively," said Moody's Vice President Mickey Chadha in an emailed statement, adding that "smaller regional supermarket chains and independents will bear the most pain."Kroger, which plunged 19% Thursday after warning on full-year earnings, sank 9.2% on Friday to a two-year low.Wal-Mart, Costco and Target shares also were big losers, along with dollar stores and drugstores with significant grocery operations. Sprouts Farmers Market was down 6.3% after losing 9.4% Thursday.Wal-Mart has been seen as a growing Amazon competitor online, reporting revived e-commerce growth in recent quarters and making several initiatives such as curbside delivery and discounts for in-store pickups. It's also made several online acquisitions, announcing Friday that it will buy Bonobos, an upscale online men's apparel site, for $310 million.But UBS' Lasser said the Amazon news may have a more limited impact on Costco and specialty stores."COST's limited assortment, low cost structure, and deep private label penetration probably means that its fortunes will be preserved, at least for the foreseeable future," Lasser wrote. "Further, the dollar stores like DG and DLTR tend to serve a customer segment that lives in rural areas or has limited resources or looking for a fill in trip. Thus, those models may not see as much change as is feared."RELATED:Amazon Is Buying Whole Foods For $13.7 Billion, Roiling SectorAmazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, EateriesCould Trump-Bezos Tension Imperil Amazon-Whole Foods Deal?Amazon's Next Big Growth Play Will Surprise You

Stocks held modest losses with a little over one hour remaining in Friday's session as Wall Street weighed weaker-than-expected housing starts and consumer confidence data, as well as a high-profile acquisition by Amazon.com (AMZN).Shares of Amazon jumped 2% on news that it's shelling out $13.7 billion to acquire Whole Foods Market (WFM). Amazon wasn't afraid to pay up for Whole Foods, because the deal values the high-end grocery chain at around $42 a share. Shares of Whole Foods jumped 28% on the news.The Dow Jones industrial average was mostly unchanged despite big drops by Wal-Mart (WMT) and Nike (NKE). The blue-chip index was buoyed by strength in Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM).The S&P 500 eased 0.1% and the Nasdaq composite gave back 0.2%. Small caps lagged with the Russell  2000 down 0.6%. Volumes on the NYSE and Nasdaq were tracking much higher than Thursday's levels as options expired.Grocery stocks fell hard on the Amazon news. Wal-Mart crashed 5% and Target (TGT) lost 7%. Costco (COST) slipped 7%.Chipmaker Impinj (PI) was seen as a potential beneficiary of the Amazon news. Amazon is a member of Impinj's RAIN alliance to promote RFID technology, which is used to better manage inventory in retail environments. Shares of Impinj soared 16% to 54.44. The emerging leader went public nearly one year ago at 14.Elsewhere, Finisar (FNSR) jumped 8%, but its 200-day moving average is looking like a resistance level for now. Earnings matched expectations, but Wall Street seemed more focused on the company's discussion of a ramp-up of 3D sensors that are widely expected to be in Apple's iPhone 8.In the biotech space, Bioverativ (BIVV) closed in on a 58.98 buy point. Shares rose nearly 2% in average volume. Bioverativ is Biogen's (BIIB) global hemophilia business and started trading as a separate stock in early February.Homebuilders didn't react much to weaker-than-expected housing data that showed starts falling 5.5% in May vs. expectations for a 3.5% rise. Meanwhile, the first reading on consumer confidence for June from the University of Michigan came in light at 94.5. The consensus estimate was for a reading of 97.1.Integrated oil firms, pipeline operators and refiners outperformed as oil prices rose slightly. U.S. crude oil for July delivery settled at $44.74 a barrel, up 28 cents. For the week, it lost 2.4%, extending its weekly losing streak to four.RELATED:Amazon Is Buying Whole Foods For $13.7 Billion; Grocery Stocks DiveThese 3 Software Giants Are Near Buys With Earnings Due Finisar Stock Pops On Expectations It Will Supply Apple iPhones

The retail stock swoon picked up on Friday after getting started late in the session on Thursday, when the White House appeared to offer the clearest sign yet that President Trump may embrace the House GOP border-tax plan that could sock retailers' earnings.Shares of Target (TGT) fell 0.7% to 63.70 on the stock market today, retreating intraday to their lowest since November 2014. Wal-Mart (WMT) slid 1.6% to 65.66, hitting an eight-month low. Other retailers that have bucked the sector's recent woes also got caught in the downdraft. Costco (COST) slipped 1.2%, while Best Buy (BBY) sank 3.9%, falling below its 50-day line.Department stores were among the hardest hit. JCPenney (JCP) tumbled 4.7% to a 1-year low while Macy's (M) lost 2.7% for its worst close since late 2011.Shares of Amazon (AMZN) were relatively unscathed, easing 0.3% to 836.30, just below a buy point. The online shopping giant is seen as less exposed to a border tax, partly because of its fast-growing web services business and partly because import taxes would be borne by Amazon sellers responsible for shipping goods to the company's fulfillment centers.According to the initial news reports on Thursday afternoon, White House press secretary Sean Spicer seemed to offer confirmation that Trump would adopt the House proposal for a 20% tax on imports. Spicer said that the wall Trump wants to build on the border with Mexico could be paid for with a 20% tax on imports from Mexico as part of the broad corporate tax reform package being developed.While the White House later clarified that the border tax was only one option being considered, that apparently did little to assuage investors' concerns. Despite unexpectedly slow annualized fourth-quarter GDP growth of 1.9% reported on Friday, major stock indexes were essentially flat in afternoon trading, suggesting that politics were behind the retail walloping.IBD'S TAKE: Big exporters like Boeing could have a negative tax rate under the GOP tax reform plan.Wal-Mart and Target officials pleaded their case in Capitol Hill meetings this week. The National Retail Federation is lobbying aggressively to block the tax, which it says could lead to an outright decline in consumer spending.Economists generally suggest that such fears are way overblown because appreciation of the dollar vs. other currencies should offset the 20% tax. Nevertheless, retailers that were hoping for a big boost to after-tax profits from tax reform are now giving off a sense of panic about how they may fare under the GOP plan.House Republicans have said they see the border-adjusted tax, which applies to imports but not exports, as a critical part of tax reform because it would raise more than $1 trillion to help pay for a reduction in the corporate rate to 20%.RELATED:Trump Backs 20% Import Tax To Pay For Border Wall — Or NotU.S. Economic Malaise Hits 11 Years: GDP Growth 1.6% In 2016Why Tax Reform Could End In Tears For Trump And GOPWhy Trump Tax Reform Could Hurt Alibaba, Other ADRs

Boeing (BA) is going to bat for the BAT — the border adjustment tax that is a central part of the GOP plan to cut the corporate tax rate.The controversial Republican tax-reform plan, which would slap a 20% tax on imports but make exports tax-free, has gotten off to a rough start in the court of public opinion. The National Retail Federation has warned that it would raise prices and cause consumer spending to decline, while analysts have said that big importers like Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT) and Best Buy (BBY) could suffer major hits to profitability.House Republicans, with the help of economists, have countered that an anticipated 20% appreciation of the dollar would neutralize those negative effects, while removing what they call a "Made in America" tax.Now big exporters including Boeing and General Electric (GE) are reportedly gearing up to help House Speaker Paul Ryan make that case, and it's not hard to understand why.Consider Boeing: The company paid an effective federal tax rate of 27.7% in 2015, when it had a current tax bill of $2.1 billion, but would have had negative tax liability under the House plan.In 2015, 59% of company revenue came from non-U.S. customers. Given that Boeing does almost all of its manufacturing and sourcing within the U.S., it has limited exposure to the 20% import tax. Meanwhile, the House GOP tax plan exempts exports from any tax.
